captions.text:
You've probably seen footage of the Tacoma
narrows bridge collapse in 1940 (if not, it's

all over the internet). And while I've heard
that in Seattle they just call it bad bridge

building, most teachers and physics textbooks
have probably told you that the bridge collapsed
because of resonance with the wind.

But they're wrong! That's because a resonance
is a vibration driven by a source oscillating

at a similar frequency - like how a swing
at the park goes higher and higher as you

push it, or the electrons in an antenna move
in tandem with the electromagnetic waves of

a radio signal, or how a guitar string vibrates
or wine glass shatters if you sing at just
the right pitch.

And that's not what happened at the Tacoma
narrows, because people at the bridge that

day measured the windspeed as being fairly
constant, or, 'not-oscillating.' So there
was no forced resonance.

It's also tempting to think that the bridge
collapsed because of vortex shedding, a cool-looking

fluid process where vortices take turns sloughing
off of the edge of an object - but that's
not right either.

What did cause the bridge to collapse is a
phenomenon called aeroelastic flutter – the

same thing that causes a strip of paper or
blade of grass to vibrate if you hold it tight

and blow straight at the edge. Basically,
with enough wind speed, the bridge started

to twist a little bit - but then gravity and
tension in the bridge caused it to twist back

down, except too far! So now the wind could
push it in the opposite direction, causing

it to twist more violently. And so on and
so forth until, well… the bridge fluttered
itself into destruction!

And aeroelastic flutter isn't just limited
to bridges - it can cause airplane wings to

hum annoyingly, or vibrate so vigorously as
to disintegrate. But don't worry - the last

time this happened on a commercial airplane
was in the early 1960s. You should probably

be more concerned with the haunted swingset
in Firmat, Argentina that can swing on its

own for days - oh wait, no, that's just aeroelastic
flutter. Sorry ghosts - physics just blew
you away.

comments.author: Touka Kureha

comments.text:
I sympathize with the desire to make a big, clear, sweeping claim, but I 
think in this case the desire has lead to overreach. You are saying the 
bridge collapsed due to "flutter", which is a kind of positive feedback 
loop in which more deflection of a surface in a wind leads to more force 
leads to more deflection and so on. That's a great insight. But you are 
also saying the bridge did NOT collapse due to resonance, which is at best 
misleading. The flutter runs away because there is not enough damping to 
take the vibrational energy imparted by the wind back out of the system. 
And THAT'S largely because the bridge begins vibrating at a resonant 
natural frequency. You can see this with your own eyes in the video: the 
bridge settles into a vivid standing wave pattern. The key characteristic 
of such a resonance--just as you say--is that it allows more and more 
vibrational energy to be added to the system--by the wind, in this case. So 
'flutter yes, resonance no' is a bad way to think about it. Better to say 
that flutter fed energy into a natural resonant vibrational mode of the 
bridge until the bridge collapsed.﻿

comments.author: Dale Peters

comments.text:
Hi! I'm a civil engineer and structural analysis is one of my favourites 
topics. I also happen to know a bit about wind effects on buildings an 
aeroelasticity so I'm going to try to shed some light here.

The video was great, but it is a bit misleading because you say that there 
was no vortex shedding involved in the collapse of the Tacoma Narrow bridge 
and that's not entirely true. In fact what caused the bridge to oscillate 
in first place was vortex shedding. This happened for several days and 
during this lapse of time the bridge would oscillate in a vertical (not 
torsional) mode. It was only during the last 45 minutes of its life that 
the bridge started to vibrate in a torsional+flexural mode due to flutter.

But had not the bridge been oscillating due to vortex shedding in first 
place, the aeroelastic phenomena probably would not have happened neither. 
This is because the flutter was probably induced by some failure of the 
bridge(degradation of its torsional stifness and the failure of some of the 
cables) during its vortex induced oscillations.

It is true that resonance is not involved during  flutter oscillations, but 
it is believed that some kind of resonance/amplification was present at the 
moment before the bridge collapsed. What caused this amplification is not 
well known and there is some debate around it and several theories. From 
what I've heard about it, the torsional motion generated a vortex wake that 
amplified the torsional oscillations but as I said before it is not clear 
and there are several mechanisms proposed in order to explain what really 
happened.

So to summarize, the secuence of the Tacoma Narrow's fail was this:

1. Vortex Induced Vibrations due to vortex shedding (vertical 
oscillations). This goes on during days.
2.Something goes down and flutter start kicking the last 45 minutes 
(flexural+torsional mode, no resonance involved)
3.Shit happens. The torsional oscillations amplify itself due to some 
mysterious mechanism (probably vortex shedding were involved but it is not 
clear) leading to the collapse of the bridge.﻿

comments.author: Firaro

comments.text:
There is little doubt that resonance of vortex shedding caused the up and 
down waves that gave the bridge its nickname, Gallopin' Gertie. On the day 
it collapsed, a cable band slipped, almost certainly because of this 
motion. The slippage of the cable band led to the torsional flutter that 
destroyed the bridge. Torsional flutter does not require the periodic input 
of energy from the wind that vortex shedding does but it appears that the 
vortex shedding was involved in the transition from the vertical motion to 
the twisting motion. One can claim then that resonance did not destroy the 
bridge. However, if there was no resonance the cable band would not have 
slipped and the torsional flutter would never have started. That is why I 
gave the jumping off a cliff analogy. The vortex shedding and resonance is 
jumping off the cliff, the torsional flutter is the sudden stop at the 
end.  I like the "Minute Physics" videos but always be wary when someone 
starts out saying how someone else is "wrong". Sometime sit takes more than 
a minute to understand the physics behind something. Maybe take 5 minutes 
to read this:

http://www.wsdot.wa.gov/tnbhistory/machine/machine3.htm﻿
comments.author: Dan Burns

comments.text:
And how the flutter is generated? by the so called 'tacoma swirly things' 
(vortices). Ther comming-off rate depends on speed of the wind, so it could 
happen *only* if wind was constant for many hours.
So constant wind caused vortices to form, vortices caused a resonance with 
natural frequency of the bridge deck. I am not sure however where the 
vortices were formed. At some edges for sure, but either deck, pillars or 
suspension lines.﻿

greater amplitude at some frequencies than at others. Frequencies at which 
the response amplitude is a relative maximum are known as the system's 
resonant frequencies, or resonance frequencies." 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resonance﻿

comments.text:
but the frequency of the aeroelastic flutter was not constant so it couldnt 
have stayed the proper frequency to break the bridge plus the frequency of 
its vibration i am pretty sure is a LOT slower than the frequency required 
to resonate with the bridge. furthermore if the aeroelastic flutter was a 
constant frequency (which if it was than it couldnt have been increasing to 
the point of destruction anyway cause constant things cannot increase and 
still be constant) a lot of things vibrate at their resonant frequency. tap 
a wooden object, make a toast with some glass, hit some metal against 
metal. these are their resonant frequencies BECAUSE they are the frequency 
the material naturally resonates at. what makes resonance so powerful is 
that something other than the object is resonating at that frequency also. 
so it more readily absorbs it adding that energy to any energy it already 
has and just keeps adding as long as you keep supplying energy at that 
frequency and the amplitude increases until it breaks. now onto tuning 
forks (if im right) when you hit something with a tuning fork it resonates 
at the resonant frequency of the object you hit and so you can get some 
pretty cool stuff out of that.

comments.text:
Well the simplest way would be to use the examples in this video like the 
swing being pushed at the right period, and the glass breaking for 
resonance from simple linear external forcing, and then introduce the 
Tacoma Narrows as resonance with self induced periodicity as an example of 
why stability analysis (even if more complex than the current syllabus) is 
important in the real world. That final point really is why it's brought up 
as an example, and you don't have to lose that.
comments.author: TIMMYISME

comments.text:
So .. while teaching students about that simple resonance, (external 
periodic force resonating an object) , should we give this dramatic 
example? and just tell. this is not QUITE what we are dealing with, its a 
lil more complicated, but none the less, the effect is resonance.. would 
that be ok? without going into any details, cause that will be way beyond 
the scope of the syllabus!
comments.author: mahesh vag

comments.text:
It's self induced resonance, in that the wind provides the power but the 
aerodynamics of the bridge provide the periodicity that results in 
self-amplifying vibrations at the natural frequency. You're correct that it 
isn't simple externally forced linear resonance, but that's not the only 
kind. The paper in the description makes this conclusion in the last 
paragraph of section IV. The video could have made this distinction clearer.
comments.author: TIMMYISME

comments.text:
"Divergence occurs when a lifting surface deflects under aerodynamic load 
so as to increase the applied load, or move the load so that the twisting 
effect on the structure is increased. The increased load deflects the 
structure further, which brings the structure to the limit loads and to 
failure. This happened to the Tacoma Narrows Bridge in Washington."
comments.author: Rohit Agrawal

comments.text:
"aeroelastic phenomena arise when structural deformations induce changes on 
aerodynamic forces. The additional aerodynamic forces cause an increase in 
the structural deformations, which leads to greater aerodynamic forces in a 
feedback process. These interactions may become smaller until a condition 
of equilibrium is reached, or may diverge catastrophically if resonance 
occurs."
comments.author: Rohit Agrawal

comments.text:
i think to call some phenomena as resonance, there must be something 
DRIVING it with its NATURAL FREQUENCY.. which is not true in this case!
comments.author: mahesh vag

comments.text:
Actually the phenomenon was first identified in the 1940s, but probably not 
applied to bridges. I asked a bridge designer if there is criteria for 
"resonance" now, but even now resonance or aeroelastic flutter in not part 
of structural design. But criteria has been introduced in codes and manuals 
that serves to prevent/minimize this kind of effect. Given complexity of 
dynamic loading, it is super-difficult to analyze dynamic resonance of 
complex structures, to the point of being infeasible.
comments.author: Rohit Agrawal

comments.text:
As for bad bridge design, it is unlikely that complex lateral force effects 
were part of codes and manuals that engineers follow. I am an architect, 
and only in the last 10-15 years have seen even seismic loads being part of 
the building code in states like new york. If aeroelastic flutter was not 
part of standard criteria for bridge design, it is hard to blame the 
engineer. Had the structure been stiff and "built like a brick shithouse" 
instead of sleek, this would not have happened.
comments.author: Rohit Agrawal

comments.text:
When I saw the video, I thought it did not look like simple mechanical 
resonance. However, the word "resonance" defines a system oscillating at 
increasing amplitudes at certain frequencies than others. So to say that 
this was not resonance is incorrect...it is certainly not "simple 
mechanical resonance" due to the twisting motion but a more complicated 
resonance caused by aeroelastic flutter.
comments.author: Rohit Agrawal

comments.text:
"Where does the energy in our bodies go when we die?" Well, simple answer. 
Our heat energy is dissipated to the surrounding air, as usual, our 
chemical energy is generally preserved until eaten by surrounding 
microorganisms, which then convert it to any form of energy they need, our 
kinetic energy (if any) is converted to heat and sound as we fall, same 
with gravitational energy. Every piece of energy can be accounted for when 
we die. Also quantum mechanics allows energy to knock stuff over etc.

comments.author: Wesker A.

comments.text:
Agreed. In fact, the producer's definition of resonance (implying that it 
is due to an excitation at a SINGLE frequency) is more incorrect than 
anything else mentioned. Resonance happens all the time, and there are very 
few environments that are very close to single frequency excitation. Even 
harmonic excitation is subject to distortion (i.e., multiple frequencies). 
But if the idea is to get kids to poke at their teachers and think more 
about a complex topic like flutter, that's good too.

fluttering in a stiff wind.

comments.text:
The actual claim is that any bridge (or any system) will oscillate at some 
frequency, and not limiting a resonance will lead to it growing ever larger 
when sufficient energy is available. By design the wind could not sway that 
bridge much, but the amount added bit by bit all day, because of resonance. 
You could also claim to debunk that an electronic circuit will oscillate 
due to resonance, because the power supply is a constant voltage. Then call 
it electro-voltaic flutter instead.
comments.author: Kenneth Florek
